journal-title-group.journal-title: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Electronics

title-group.article-title: Enhanced LED-light-driven photocatalytic antibacterial by g-C3N4/BiOI composites

institution-wrap.institution: School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering
School of Material Science and Engineering

permissions.copyright-statement: © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC, part of Springer Nature 2018
permissions.copyright-holder: Springer Science+Business Media, LLC, part of Springer Nature

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: g-C3N4/BiOI composites with different ratios were prepared by in-situ generation route at room temperature and applied in antibacterial investigation. Detailed information of the composites was characterized by XRD, TEM, HRTEM, SEM, EDS, BET, XPS, FT–IR, UV–Vis, photocurrent and EIS. The obtained g-C3N4/BiOI composites presented excellent antibacterial performance toward Escherichia coli (E. coli) and Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus) under LED track light, with the complete inactivation of bacterial within 30 min. The decomposition of bacterial cells was observed by SEM. The bacterial mechanism was investigated by trapping experiments: holes (h+), superoxide anion free radical (O2−) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) were identified as active species for bacterial inactivation, and h+ had a main effect in the antibacterial process. The enhanced photocatalytic activities were assigned to an efficient separation and transition of electrons (e−) and h+ in photocatalytic antibacterial process. This work indicated the g-C3N4/BiOI composites are promising photocatalytic antibacterial materials for water disinfection.

institution-wrap.institution: National Natural Science Foundation of China (CN)
National Natural Science Foundation of China

custom-meta.meta-value: Springer Science+Business Media, LLC, part of Springer Nature

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Waterborne bacteria/viruses pose a great threat to human health. Although microorganisms can be inactivated by strategies, such as chlorination [1], ozonization [2], UV irradiation and filtration [3]. However, these technologies also showed some drawbacks, such as high cost, harmful by-products, and low efficiency. It is an urgent need to establish an efficient and environment-friendly approach. Photocatalytic technology based on semiconductor materials can be deemed as a low-cost, environment-friendly advanced oxidation technology and a green way that can inactivate all kinds of microorganisms efficiently [4–7]. For the traditional photocatalytic materials, such as TiO2 and ZnO [8–10], there are low efficiency of quantum conversion, poor visible light response and low utilization of solar energy, it is difficult to satisfy the needs of practical applications. Therefore, fabricating novel photocatalytic material with high quantum efficiency, wide spectral response and friendly environment is an interesting work in the field of photocatalytic antibacterial research [11, 12].

Among many visible light-responsive photocatalytic materials, carbon nitride (g-C3N4), a polymer semiconductor graphite phase carbonitride, attracts much attention due to its metal-free composition, low cost, structural stability and unique structure of electron band [13–15]. For the monomer g-C3N4, because of rapid combination of the photogenerated e− and h+, the h+ on the valence band (VB) of g-C3N4 are not sufficient for the degradating pollutions and inactivating the microorganisms in the environment efficiently. Therefore, nanostructured g-C3N4 with large surface area has been designed to improve the performance of g-C3N4 under visible light [16–21]. Furthermore, the composites based on g-C3N4 have been investigated in photocatalyst antibacterial field, for example, Ag–ZnO/g-C3N4 [22], Ag/g-C3N4 [23, 24], RGO/g-C3N4 [25], TiO2/g-C3N4 [26] etc. By combining materials (Ag, RGO) with good electric ability or semiconductor (ZnO, TiO2), the composites showed enhanced photocatalytic performance due to the efficient separation of e− and h+.

With a narrow band gap (1.77 eV), BiOI have been regarded as one of the most promising material to decontaminate water [27–30]. At present, there have been a lot of investigation on BiOI photocatalytic antibacterial materials, such as BiOI–AgI [31], Ag@AgI/Bi–BiOI [32], Ag/BiOI [33], Ti/BiOI [34] etc. By constructing heterostructures, the activity of these composite catalysts can be enhanced due to the efficient separation of e− and h+. Recently, BiOI and g-C3N4 were coupled to construct g-C3N4/BiOI composites [35–40], which were applied to resolve environmental problems, such as the degradation of MO [35], MB [35, 36], RhB [35, 40] etc. However, the investigation of g-C3N4/BiOI composites were mainly focused on the degradation of pollution, there is only one work in the field of photocatalytic antibiosis [41]. In their work, the xenon was selected as the light source and the antibacterial process lasted 7 h against E. coli. In view of excellent performance of g-C3N4/BiOI composites in degradation of pollution and the preliminary exploration on antibacterial, the obtained g-C3N4/BiOI composites are anticipated to show high photocatalytic performance towards photocatalytic antibacterial field.

In this study, g-C3N4/BiOI composites were synthesized based on in-situ generation method at room temperature. Results showed that g-C3N4/BiOI composites presented high photocatalytic performance towards the destroying of E. coli and S. aureus. Meanwhile, all the antibacterial experiments were carried out under LED track light irradiation (In this work, it was noted as LED light, the emission wavelength: 450 ± 10 nm), which is stable, low energy-consuming and environmentally-friendly. Compared with previous reported literature [41], our work broadened the scope of antibacterial research, shortened the antibacterial time and improved the antibacterial performance: the obtained g-C3N4/BiOI composites could kill E. coli and S. aureus within 30 min under LED light. Moreover, the g-C3N4/BiOI composites were characterized by various tests, and the mechanism of the photocatalytic antibacterial process was investigated by trapping experiments.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: All reagents (from Sinopharm Company) were used without being purified. Distilled water was applied to every experiment in this work.

sec.title: Synthesis of g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/BiOI
sec.p: g-C3N4 was obtained by the traditional calcination route. Firstly, urea was added to alumina crucible. Under air atmosphere, the temperature was raised up to 160 °C with 20 ℃/min heating rate and kept for 1 h in muffle furnace. Then, the temperature was raised to 520 °C with the same heating rate and kept for 2 h. Finally, the product was cooled to 25 °C and then yellow g-C3N4 was collected.

g-C3N4/BiOI composites were prepared by in-situ generation method at room temperature. 0.97 g Bi(NO3)3·5H20 and 0.176 g g-C3N4 were put into in 30 mL ethylene glycol (EG) under ultrasonication for 1 h to form solution A; 0.332 g KI and 0.08 g NaOH were put into in 40 mL distilled water to form solution B; the solution B was added drop by drop into the solution A by stirring for 1 h. Then, the obtained sediments were washed by distilled water and ethyl alcohol several times. Finally, the obtained sample was dried at 60 °C, which was named as 20% g-C3N4/BiOI (the mass content of g-C3N4 in the composite was 20%). Similarly, 10% g-C3N4/BiOI and 30% g-C3N4/BiOI composite were synthesized by adjusting the content of g-C3N4.

sec.title: Materials characterization
sec.p: The crystal phase of photocatalyst was tested by X-ray powder diffraction (Shimadzu XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer) at a scan rate of 7 °C/min. The morphologies were observed by transmission electron microscope (JEOL JEM-2010) and scanning electron microscope (JEOLJSM-7001F), which was equipped with an energy-dispersive spectroscope (EDS). The pore size and pore distribution were conducted by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) (TriStar II 3020 surface area and porosity analyzer). The surface species of the composite were obtained by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) with a monochromatic Mg Kα source. The functional groups of the samples were detected by using a fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FT–IR). The absorption performance of light was analyzed through a UV–Vis diffuse reflection spectroscopy (DRS) (Shimadzu UV-2450 spectrophotometer). The photocurrent and the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were measured by the electrochemical workstation (CHI 760B Chenhua Instrument Company). The antimicrobial performance of g-C3N4/BiOI composites was estimated by LED track light (Shenzhen Hanwen Lighting Technology Company).

sec.title: Electrochemical experiments
sec.p: The photocurrent and the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were measured by the electrochemical workstation. The preparation procedures of working electrodes were as follows: First of all, 5 mg sample was dissolved in 1 mL EG to make a slurry. Then, 20 µL suspensions were coated into indium tin oxide (ITO) glass with 1 cm × 0.5 cm area. Finally, the electrode was dried at 60 °C for 2 h. Besides, platinum plate and saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as the counter electrode and the reference electrode, respectively. 0.1 M Na2SO4 and 0.1 M KCl solution containing 5 mM Fe(CN)63−/(Fe(CN)64−) were used as the electrolyte in the photocurrent and EIS, respectively.

sec.title: Antibacterial activity
sec.p: The antimicrobial performance of g-C3N4/BiOI composites was estimated by using E. coli and S. aureus as the model of bacteria, 35 W LED light as the light source. All the glasswares and nutrient agar related in the experiment were sterilized at 121 °C for 30 min. The bacterial grew in the nutrient broth at 37 °C for 16 h under agitating at 180 rpm. The received bacteria suspensions was centrifuged at 10000 rpm for 6 min and washed with sterilized saline solution (0.85% NaCl) several times to exclude the impact of the fluid medium. Then the bacterial particles were suspended in a sterilized salt solution. The bacteria level for antibacterial process was 107 colony forming units (CFU)/mL, which was modulated by gradient dilution using sterilized saline (0.85% NaCl).

The sample was added to a saline solution containing bacteria (concentration of sample was 0.2 mg/mL). Under aseptic conditions, the LED light was turned out, and the mixed solution with catalyst and bacteria were sucked out at 0 min, 5 min, 10 min, 20 min, and 30 min, respectively. Then, at the end of reaction, the 100 µL mixed solution with catalyst and bacteria were coated evenly on the culture medium, and then the culture mediums were placed in the incubator at 37 °C for 18 h. All the experiments were parallel to three times, and the data shown in this paper were the average of three times.

sec.title: XRD analysis
sec.p: To determine the crystal structure of BiOI, g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/BiOI composites, X-ray powder diffraction spectra were presented in Fig. 1. For g-C3N4, the diffraction peak at 13.1° corresponded to the (100) crystal face, which was assigned to the structure of the triazine ring; the peak at 27.4° corresponded to the (002) crystal plane, which belonged to the stacking peak of the conjugated aromatic ring [42–44]. For BiOI, the diffraction peaks were assigned to (001), (002), (012), (110), (013), (004), (020), (114), (212) crystal plane, which was consistent with the standard BiOI card (JCPDS10-0445) [45]. For g-C3N4/BiOI composites, the diffraction peaks were assigned to BiOI, and there were no obvious diffraction peaks of g-C3N4. The result is probably attributed to low contents of g-C3N4 in the g-C3N4/BiOI composites and weak crystalline properties of g-C3N4.

caption.p: XRD patterns of the BiOI, g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/BiOI composites

sec.title: Morphological analysis
sec.p: The morphology of BiOI, g-C3N4, 20% g-C3N4/BiOI composite were investigated by TEM (Fig. 2A–C), HRTEM (Fig. 2D, E) and SEM (Fig. 2F). For BiOI, it could be observed flower like microstructure with plenty of nanosheets (Fig. 2A). In case of g-C3N4, lamellar structure were observed clearly (Fig. 2B). For 20% g-C3N4/BiOI composite, BiOI nanosheets (dark area) overlapped with g-C3N4 (gray area) each other (Fig. 2C), indicating the successful formation of heterojunction between BiOI and g-C3N4. As the heterojunction interface could facilitate the separation of e− and h+ to improve photocatalytic efficiency, in order to further understand heterojunction interface, the HRTEM images were obtained and shown in Fig. 2D, E. From Fig. 2D, it could be found the BiOI nanosheets (black area) attaching to the surface of g-C3N4 (grey area). The area marked by red box in Fig. 2D was enlarged in Fig. 2E. As can be observed in Fig. 2E, the lattice fringes have a spacing of 0.458 nm, corresponding to interplanar spacing of (002) of BiOI (JCPDF 10–0045). The results are accordance with the XRD results (Fig. 1). Figure 2F, G showed the SEM image and EDS spectrum of 20% g-C3N4/BiOI composite, respectively. Clearly, the BiOI nanoflowers were attached on the g-C3N4 nanosheets (Fig. 2F), which displayed a good combination of g-C3N4 and BiOI. EDS indicated the existence of C, N, O, Bi and I element in the 20% g-C3N4/BiOI composite. It should be noted that Si element originates from silicon base. Based on the TEM, HRTEM, SEM and EDS analysis, it can be concluded that the heterojunction structure formed in the g-C3N4/BiOI composites.

caption.p: TEM images of A BiOI, B g-C3N4, C 20% g-C3N4/BiOI composite; D HRTEM of 20% g-C3N4/BiOI composite; E magnified image of the area noted by red circle in D; F SEM of 20% g-C3N4/BiOI composite; G EDS of the area noted by red box in F. (Color figure online)

sec.title: BET analysis
sec.p: In order to investigate the surface property changing of the g-C3N4/BiOI composites after introducing g-C3N4 into BiOI, the SBET dates were obtained. The SBET of 10% g-C3N4/BiOI, 20% g-C3N4/BiOI and 30% g-C3N4/BiOI composites are 26.50 m2 g−1, 29.45 m2 g−1 and 44.38 m2 g−1, respectively, which are much higher than that of pure BiOI (13.87 m2 g−1). In view of the large surface area g-C3N4 (96.01 m2 g−1), the SBET of g-C3N4/BiOI composites increases with the increasing weight content of g-C3N4. This fact implies that the existence of g-C3N4 is favorable for the formation of high specific surface areas of g-C3N4/BiOI composites.

sec.title: XPS analysis
sec.p: The surface species and chemical states of 20% g-C3N4/BiOI composite were investigated by XPS spectra (Fig. 3). The high resolution peaks of Bi 4f XPS spectra of the sample were at about 158.9 and 164.1 eV (Fig. 3A), which were according to the characteristic of Bi 4f7/2 and Bi 4f5/2 [37, 46]. The O 1 s peak was at 529.7 eV (Fig. 3B), which was assigned as the Bi–O bond in [Bi2O2] layer of BiOI [37, 46]. For I 3d spectrum, the peaks located at 618.8 and 630.3 eV (Fig. 3C) corresponded to the binding energies of I 3d5/2 and I 3d3/2 [37, 46]. For C 1 s spectrum (Fig. 3D), it can be observed two distinct peaks at 284.7, 288.1 eV and a weak peak at 286.1 eV. The peak at 284.7 was attributed to the adventitious carbon on the surface of g-C3N4, and the peak at 288.1 eV was ascribed to a C–N–C coordination [47, 48], while the weak peak at about 286.1 eV may be assigned to the C–NH2 species [37]. For N 1 s spectrum (Fig. 3E), three fitting peaks were present at about 400.1, 399.1 and 398.4 eV, respectively. The three peaks could be assigned as the free amino groups (C–N–H), the tertiary nitrogen N−(C)3 groups and the sp2 hybridized nitrogen involved in triazine rings (C–N = C) [49]. In view of the low loading of g-C3N4, only weak intensity signals of XPS were observed for C 1 s and N 1 s. These XPS results confirmed the successful synthesis of g-C3N4/BiOI composites.

caption.p: XPS spectra of 20% g-C3N4/BiOI composite. A Bi 4f; B O 1 s; C I 3d; D C 1 s; E N 1 s

sec.title: FT-IR analysis
sec.p: FT-IR spectra of the BiOI, g-C3N4, g-C3N4/BiOI composites were shown in Fig. 4. The peak at 808 cm−1 was assigned to out-of-plane bending modes of heterocyclic C–N [50]. Several peaks appearing from 1200 to 1650 cm−1 belonged to stretching vibration peak of typical aromatic C–N [51–53]. For BiOI, the peak at 478 cm−1 was attributed to the stretching vibration of the Bi–O bond [35]. For g-C3N4/BiOI composites, the characteristic absorption peaks of BiOI and g-C3N4 were all presented, the results confirmed the g-C3N4/BiOI composites were prepared successfully.

caption.p: FT-IR spectra of BiOI, g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/BiOI composites

sec.title: DRS analysis
sec.p: To reflect the optical properties of the composites, the spectra of UV–Vis diffuse reflectance was presented in Fig. 5A. The absorption edge of g-C3N4 appeared at 460 nm, which was in accordance with the previous reports on g-C3N4 [40]. For BiOI, the absorption edge appeared at 680 nm, which confirmed its excellent visible light absorption performance [54]. In terms of g-C3N4/BiOI composites, the absorption edge was at about 670 nm. Compared with g-C3N4, the composites showed better visible-light absorbability. The result indicated g-C3N4/BiOI composites could absorb visible light and e− could be generated in photocatalytic process.

caption.p: A The UV–Vis absorption spectra of the BiOI, g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/BiOI composites; B Energy band gap of BiOI; C Energy band gap of g-C3N4

sec.p: where: Ee is the energy of free electrons on the hydrogen scale (about 4.5 eV); X is the electronegativity of the semiconductor (the X of BiOI is 5.94 eV [57–59] and the X of g-C3N4 is 4.72 eV [48, 56], respectively). So, the VB and CB of the BiOI were figured out as 2.31 eV and 0.57 eV, respectively. The VB and CB of the g-C3N4 were 1.64 eV and − 1.2 eV, repectively.

sec.title: Photocurrent and EIS analysis
sec.p: Photocurrent and EIS were taken to investigate the separation efficiency of e− and h+ in the g-C3N4/BiOI composites (Fig. 6). The photocurrent-time curves of BiOI, g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/BiOI composites were shown in Fig. 6A. It could be observed that all the g-C3N4/BiOI composites have higher current intensity than g-C3N4 and BiOI. At the same time, the current intensity of 20% g-C3N4/BiOI composite was about 4 times as that of BiOI and 2 times as that of g-C3N4, indicating the e−–h+ separated efficiency of g-C3N4/BiOI composites are higher than g-C3N4 and BiOI. In addition, the current intensity almost did not decline after seven times cycles under the LED light, which indicated that the materials were stable. EIS was taken to further investigate the charge carrier transfer properties of the samples (Fig. 6B). For g-C3N4/BiOI composites, the spectrum showed a smaller Nyquist radius than g-C3N4 and BiOI, indicating the more efficient e−–h+ separation efficiency in the composite. The result was similar with the literature reported [60]. Based on above results, the hybrid structure existed between g-C3N4 and BiOI, promoting an efficient charge separation and leading an improved photcatalytic antibacterial performance.

caption.p: A Photocurrent of BiOI, g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/BiOI composites; B EIS of BiOI, g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/BiOI composites

sec.title: Antibacterial analysis
sec.p: The antibacterial performance of obtained composites was estimated by E. coli and S. aureus under LED light. In the case of g-C3N4/BiOI composites without light irradiation, the livability of bacterium did not change after 30 min, indicating that the material itself was not toxic to E. coli and S. aureus [22–26]. Similarly, In direct LED light irradiation and without catalysts, the livability of bacterium did not change after 30 min, indicating the LED light could not inactivate E. coli and S. aureus directly. When catalysts and light irradiation were both present, the livability of bacterial reduced significantly with the extension of reaction time. For pure BiOI and g-C3N4, 74.38% and 86.19% E. coli bacterial cells were inactivated within 30 min, respectively (Fig. 7A, C). Compared with g-C3N4 and BiOI, the composites showed efficient photocatalytic antibacterial activity for E. coli, among them, the antibacterial rate of 10% g-C3N4/BiOI and 30% g-C3N4/BiOI could reached 96.56% and 98.31% within 30 min. Remarkably, 20% g-C3N4/BiOI composite showed the optimal bactericidal effect and E. coli were inactivated completely within 30 min. In the case of S. aureus (Fig. 7B, D), the prepared g-C3N4/BiOI composites also showed better antibacterial performance than pure g-C3N4 and BiOI. All of the composites could kill S. aureus within 30 min. Significantly, S. aureus was inactivated rapidly by 20% g-C3N4/BiOI composite within 20 min, while 77.22% and 84.90% S. aureus were inactivated for pure g-C3N4 and BiOI within 30 min.

caption.p: Bactericidal efficiency against AE. coli and BS. aureus with different samples; Photocatalytic antibacterial activities of (a) BiOI, (b) g-C3N4 and (c) 20% g-C3N4/BiOI composite against CE. coli and DS. aureus at different irradiation times under LED light

sec.p: The comparisons of photocatalytic activities of the g-C3N4/BiOI composites with various related g-C3N4-based and BiOI-based photocatalysts previously reported for the photocatalytic antibacterial of E. coli and S. aureus were listed in Table. 1. As can be seen, the E. coli and S. aureus antibacterial ratio of g-C3N4/BiOI composite were 100% under 35 W low-energy LED light, which is better than g-C3N4-based and BiOI-based photocatalysts (Under Mercury lamp, Xenon lamp, Gallium iodine lamp). This signifies that g-C3N4/BiOI composites have great potentials for the antibacterial of microorganisms in water.

caption.p: Comparison with other g-C3N4-based and BiOI-based photocatalysts in the literature

table-wrap-foot.p: BC bacterial concentration; AR antibacterial ratio; NA not available; ML mercury lamp; XL xenon lamp; GIL gallium iodine lamp

sec.p: To investigate the structure and morphology changes of E. coli in the destruction process, SEM was taken to observe the images of bacteria at different photocatalytic time. At the beginning of photocatalytic sterilization, the form of bacterial cells was complete (Fig. 8A). When the sample was irradiated for 5 min, bacteria began to deform (Fig. 8B). After 10 min of irradiation, the bacteria became out of shape and the surface of the bacteria was sunken (Fig. 8C). The cell walls of E. coli were destroyed and the morphology of the bacteria changed significantly after 20 min of irradiation (Fig. 8D). Then the membrane of bacteria is seriously damaged, and the bacteria are completely inactivated after 30 min of irradiation (Fig. 8E). These results indicated g-C3N4/BiOI composites could destroy the bacteria, and some active species, such as h+, e−, hydroxyl radical (·OH), H2O2, and ·O2− may be present in the antibacterial process, which may play a certain role on the bacterial cells.

caption.p: SEM images of E. coli photocatalytically treated with 20% g-C3N4/BiOI composite under LED light irradiation for A 0 min, B 5 min, C 10 min, D 20 min and E 30 min

sec.title: Disinfection mechanisms
sec.p: To explore the sterilized mechanism of g-C3N4/BiOI composites, trapping experiments were applied in this work to find the major active species during the antibacterial process. The effects of Na2C2O4 (1 mmol L−1), Cr(VI) (0.05 mmol L−1), isopropanol (1 mmol L−1) and catalase (0.05 mmol L−1) were investigated in 20% g-C3N4/BiOI photocatalytic antibacterial system for the capture of h+, e−, OH and H2O2, respectively. In addition, N2 was injected into the solution to remove O2 and then inhibited the formation of ·O2−. The concentration of each capture agent was consistent with the reported concentration to ensure maximum capture and was non-toxic to bacteria [61–64]. As shown in Fig. 9, photocatalytic effects were almost the same in the case of Cr(VI) and isopropanol, all the E. coli bacterial cells were inactivated within 30 min. The results indicated that e− and·OH were not the dominant species in g-C3N4/BiOI photocatalytic system; in the case of passing N2 and adding the catalase, the photocatalytic effects reduced, there were 82.55% and 74.67% E. coli bacterial cells were inactivated within 30 min, respectively. It indicated that ·O2− and H2O2 took effects on the antibacterial. However, when Na2C2O4 was applied to consume h+, only about 19% E. coli bacteria were inactivated after 30 min of irradiation, the sterilized efficiency was reduced significantly. The results showed that the h+ played a leading role during bacterial inactivation.

caption.p: Bactericidal efficiency of E. coli with different capture agents under LED light

sec.p: Based on the previous discussion and analysis, the dual charge transfer mechanism was produced in this study (Fig. 10). First of all, based on the DRS data, the CB potentials of BiOI, g-C3N4 was 0.57 eV, − 1.2 eV, respectively. The VB potentials of BiOI, g-C3N4 were 2.31 eV, 1.64 eV, respectively. The specific photocatalytic process is as follows: g-C3N4 and BiOI were excited by LED light irradiation and e− and h+ were generated. The h+ on the VB of BiOI transferred to the VB of g-C3N4 and the e− on the CB of g-C3N4 transferred to the CB of BiOI. Since the potential energy of the VB of g-C3N4 is less than the energy of ·OH/H2O (Eθ(·OH/H2O) = 2.27 eV) [65], h+ at the VB of g-C3N4 could not react with H2O to produce ·OH, h+ would react with the bacteria directly to inactivate the bacteria. In the meantime, the potential energy of the CB of BiOI is higher than the energy of O2/·O2− (Eθ (O2/·O2−) =− 0.33 eV) [40], e− on the CB of g-C3N4 could not generate ·O2−. However, there still exists some electrons that did not transfer to the CB of g-C3N4, which could react with O2 and then generate ·O2−and H2O2 in the system [66, 67]. The two active species ·O2−and H2O2 could play a certain role in inactivating E. coli in the process, which was in accordance with the result of trapping experiments. Hence, the dual charge transfer mechanism was confirmed, and similar transfer mechanism was presented in the previous report [31, 32]. Based on above analysis, h+, ·O2− and H2O2 were active species, among them, h+ played the main role in the antibacterial process.

caption.p: Photocatalytic antibacterial mechanism diagram of the g-C3N4/BiOI composites under LED light

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, efficient photocatalyst g-C3N4/BiOI catalysts were prepared by in-situ generation method at room temperature. The composites showed excellent photocatlytic performance toward E. coli and S. aureus under LED light irradiation, and the bacterial were completely inactivated within 30 min. The enhanced photocatalytic properties were attributed to efficient separation of e− and h+ in the g-C3N4/BiOI composites. Based on trapping experiments, h+, ·O2− and H2O2 were active species and dual charge transfer mechanism was confirmed in the photocatalytic sterilization process. As the excellent performance for inactivating E. coli and S. aureus, g-C3N4/BiOI composites could be applied as a promising material in terms of water disinfection.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: National Nature Science Foundation of China (Grant Nos. 21406094, 21506079 and 51572114), Postdoctoral Foundation of China (Grant No. 2015M571693) and Foundation of Jiangsu University (Grant No. 14JDG184) were genuinely appreciated.
